text:
Okay, let me say that I don't think just giving this 5 stars will express how much my fiance loved these sandwiches. Direct quotes from him: "This is the best thing to ever come out of a crockpot in the history of cooking", "I would eat my way out of a bathtub of this". LOL! Seriously, if we weren't already engaged, this stuff would have made him propose on the spot. :) The only change I made was to shred the chicken after 5 hours and then put it back into the crockpot to let it soak up all the sauce for another 2 hours. I served the meat on toasted Kaiser rolls with melted pepperjack cheese. Thank you very much, needless to say this will be a VERY regularly made recipe in our house! :)

text:
I would give this more stars if I could!  This was sooooo good!!  I "kind of" doubled the recipe.  I used a 2.5# bag of frozen boneless chicken tenders and tossed in two 12 oz. bottles of Frank's Wing Sauce, a whole package of ranch dressing mix & 1/4 cup butter.  I let it all cook together instead of adding sauce and butter at the end.  This was plenty saucy and I think I will go with 3# of chicken next time (the leftovers are great)!  Also great to use on the buffalo chicken pizza recipe on this site. I served this on crusty french bread with cheese and pepper rings.  I am making this for the next party that comes around and I know it will be a hit.  Thanks so much for sharing the recipe!

text:
This went over amazingly well with hubby and his buddies. I had a problem with my hot sauce evaporating about half way through the process, so I ended up adding the rest of the 23 oz bottle, which made it a bit too spicy . I enjoyed the little zip the ranch powder added to the chicken. Next time I make this I'll probably use some chicken broth for the first half of the cooking time and then add the hot sauce. I served the sandwiches with colby-jack cheese, shredded lettuce, and ranch dressing. I'm planning to use the leftovers for Buffalo Chicken pizza. Thanks for another great variation on buffalo chicken.

text:
This is awesome! The first time i made it I followed the recipe exactly and it was too spicey for my family. The second time I made it I used a 2 1/2lb bag frozed chicken tenderloins, 1 bottle of Franks Wing Sauce, a whole packet of ranch, 1/4c butter and 2 8oz whipped cream cheese (to tone down the spice). I put the cream cheese and butter at the bottom of the crock pot, then put the chicken on top and poured the bottle of wing sauce over it along with the packet of ranch. My family LOVED it!! The cream cheese really toned down the spiceyness! We had this o n samdwichs and I bought Boboli pizza crust, brushed it with olive oil and fresh minced garlic, baked it for 10 minutes, then spread ranch dressing on crust, spead buffalo chicken on next and topped with mozz. cheese. That was fabulous!!!

text:
This was ok.  I love hot wings so I have to say I missed the skin.  I think this dish could use a bit of thigh meat, perhaps, to give a bit more chicken flavor & fat to it.  (As my husband would say 'fat is where the flavor is'.)  I also think it could do with a little less cook time because it does (especially with all white meat) dry out the meat and the end result for me was sauced dry bland breast meat.  I think I'll try it again with the modifications I mentioned.

text:
Update (5/5/12): I have made this quite a few times and have finally perfected taste and spice. I place 2 lbs of thawed boneless chicken breasts in the crock pot with 1/4 bottle of Frank's Redhot Wings Sauce and drizzle with ranch dressing (instead of dry packet). Cook on low for 3 hours and shred.  Add remainder of hot sauce and cook for 1 more hour. Add more ranch (to desired taste) and butter and serve. I like them with cheddar cheese on onion rolls or toasted hoagie rolls. Cooking with the entire bottle of hot sauce makes them very spicy.

I wanted to try this recipe, and I didn't have time to go get "the buffalo wing sauce", so I made a mix of Frank's hot sauce and melted butter. Great flavor, and I liked alot, but it was too spicy for my family.  Also, I got home late from work, and it cooked 9 hours instead of 7-8. Totally my fault, of course,and the chicken was overcooked (getting mushy), so I will only make again, only when I can time it correctly. Still was very good with my (couldn't-help-it-this-time)changes. Now, I can't wait to try exactly! Thanks, "crazycatlady", from the "Recipe Exchange", for suggesting, and Divinesoalc21 for an easy,why-didn't-I-think-of-that, delicious recipe!

userID:
3851884
Display Name:
psdesertcooker
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As a Buffalo chicken fan I have to say this recipe is incredible. Being that I am trying to watch what I am eating makes it even better because you get all the flavor without frying and all the fatty skin. Also this is not only good on sandwiches but also as soft taco meat, on wraps, and in salads. I also used it with some brown rice and vegetables.   I took a lot of the tips from previous reviewers and struck upon the perfect combination to solve any of the problems from people who gave it bad reviews. This is what I did:  In place of 4 boneless breasts I used 3 very large bone-in breasts.  Instead of the ranch dressing packets I made my own ranch seasoning. I did not add any salt to the ranch dressing seasing I made, just used the herbs and spices (There is enough salt in the hot sauce).  After 5 hours, I deboned the chicken and shredded it slightly and put it back in the sauce. This keeps it perfectly moist and tender.  Rather than butter I spinkled it a bit with "Molly McButter". I like it really hot and using that just toned it down ever so slightly.  I used Franks "Red Hot" Buffalo sauce and it was in no way too hot for me. For the others complaining it was too hot use a milder sauce or add more butter. That will tone it down. Also I think by making your own Ranch Seasoning any problems with it being too salty will be eliminated, just remember not to add salt to your homemade ranch dressing seasoning recipe if it calls for it.

I LOVE this recipe! I do just throw the entire bottle of sauce in with the chicken, and I leave out the butter. I also normally throw in frozen chicken breasts, and cook on low ~7-8 hours (while I'm sleeping) We serve it on rolls with ranch dressing and provolone. Display Name:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is incredibly easy to throw together, and really tasty! I used 3 large FROZEN chicken breasts and poured 3/4 of the hot sauce (Original Frank's) with half the ranch packet on top. After reading many reviews, I was leery of the hot sauce evaporating, so I added 1/4 cup of chicken broth. I cooked it on low for about 4 hours, then shredded the chicken and put it back into the crockpot to soak up the sauce. At this point I also added in the remaining 1/4 cup of hot sauce, along with the butter. I cooked it for an additional hour on low, and it turned out WONDERFUL! It was so tender and moist. I think that adding *frozen* chicken breasts helped to prevent the chicken from over-cooking to the point of dryness. I served it as sliders: I cut dinner rolls in half, toasted them in the broiler, and topped the sandwiches with shredded cheddar cheese and lettuce. I was initially going to give this recipe 4 stars, but my boyfriend exclaimed that this is one of the BEST dishes I have ever cooked for him...and wants me to make it for his family. So 5 stars it is! :)

text:
Good starting point and good flavor, but I took the sggestion of many of the previous reviewers and used Frank's Original Hot Sauce.  Talk about salty! We could barely eat this!   I calculated that the hot sauce alone in this recipe provides 3400 mg of sodium per serving (and that is before adding the salt in the butter, ranch mix, etc) - given that the daily recommended allowance is less than 2400 mg, a person would get well over what is considered a healthy amount for an entire day in the meat alone!  I did like the ease of preparation and flavor (take away most of the salt), and I will probably make this again but use Tabasco and a tad of garlic powder, and add cayenne for added heat (since Frank's is basically Tabasco with a bit of garlic powder, a touch more cayenne, and a ton of salt  - Tabasco has 30 mg sodium per tsp while Frank's has 200!).  I'll let you know how it turns out.  I made the sandwiches on warmed Hoagie rolls with Provolone, and served this with Original Blue Cheese coleslaw (from this site) and fresh fruit, which made for good counterpoints to the heat and salt of the sandwich.

text:
I took this to my last work luncheon and received rave reviews!  I kept to the heart of the recipe but took a couple of the suggestions from other reviewers...to make 24 sliders (double this recipe): 4 large boneless skinless chicken breasts and 6 small boneless skinless chicken thighs and I used one bottle of mild buffalo wing sauce and one regular buffalo wing sauce...all other ingredients as written.  As a time saver and to cut down on mess, I discovered if you use a hand held potato masher you can break up the chicken in the crock pot to the consistency you want easily without any mess or fuss.

text:
Although I like buffalo sauce, I must be a wimp because this was too spicy for me. I bought Franks Red Hot buffalo wing sauce and used the whole bottle since it was 12 oz. I also accidentally used a whole packet of ranch and it was totally fine. Also, when it was done cooking, I took out the sauce with the chicken and spooned some back in so it wouldn't be sopping. It would have been swimming in sauce if I hadn't done that. Think I used about a pound of chicken, maybe a little more. You can put the breasts in the crockpot frozen to save time - I cooked on low for 8 hours and chicken was not dry. I know they warn against using frozen meat in the crock pot but I've always done it and always been fine so I'm taking my chances.

text:
This was so tasty!  I only made a couple of changes, as per some other reviews. After 5 hours, I shredded the chicken and put it back in the pot, along with the butter.  I served it on rolls that I broiled to melt butter and crumbled blue cheese on them.    I only take a star away because I really think it matters to shred the chicken five hours in.  Also, I used 3 chicken breasts and only 12 oz of wing sauce and it was just fine; I think 17.5 oz might be a bit much.  So yummy!  Will definitely make this again!

text:
This is incredible!  Ridiculously easy, too.  My chicken breasts were huge so I only used 3 but they still totaled 1 1/2 pounds.  I was skeptical of the amount of buffalo wing sauce (used Frank's of course and the bottle was only 12 ounces) so just added 3/4 cup, and used the entire packet of ranch mix.  My chicken was still partly frozen but it was cooked and ready to shred in 6 hours.  The chicken was completely delicious.  Moist, tender, saucy, perfect amount of heat.  We devoured these and I plan to use some of the leftovers to make a buffalo chicken pizza.  It would have been too hot with the whole amount of wing sauce though.  As my mom says, you can always add more but you can't take anything out!

text:
A really delicious, different way to make chicken in the slow cooker. I made as written and thought it was awesome. Next time I'll try adding a full pack of ranch, just because I don't like the half pack sitting around and we do love our ranch flavor. I cooked for the full seven hours on low and the breasts practically shred themselves in the crock, they were so tender. Served on ciabatta rolls browned in a skillet with butter on the cut halves, provolone on mine and pepperjack on his: we were both very satisfied. Thanks so much for sharing :)

A big hit for potluck of 12 ppl with the following changes! 6 breasts, 6 thighs, 2 btl(12 oz) buffalo wing sauce, 1 can low sodium tomato soup, 2T butter, low sodium ranch dressing mix. 5 hrs on low, shred, 1 hr on low. text:
The heat of this recipe will depend on your buffalo wing sauce.  Franks does make a mild sauce people!  If you don't like it hot, don't use the hot variety!  I used a bit of hot Franks buffalo wing sauce and more of the hot and spicy Franks BBQ sauce.  I made my own dry ranch dressing mix from a recipe here on AR and used the whole recipe. I never added butter.  I also used 6 frozen chicken tenderloins.  They cooked in my slow cooker on low in 3 hours.  Yes the chicken was spicy hot but that is a function of the sauce I used.  I dumped in some bottled ranch dressing and we toned down the sandwiches with some cole slaw.  It was very good.  This is a good basic recipe which you can alter to you own tastes.  Thanks!

text:
YUM!  I love hot wings, so I had a feeling I would like this.  I was right!  Hubby liked it too, and he doesn't like wings (he doesn't like any meat with bones in it).  It went over very well at our LAN party. Lots of compliments and second (and third) helpings.  I made my sandwich with white American cheese, Blue Cheese dressing for the buns, and celery sticks on the side, but most of the guys just had their sandwiches plain.  Some reviewers complained that the chicken mixture dried out in the crock pot, but I had rather the opposite problem.  My shredded chicken mixture was positively soupy.  It made for some messy sandwiches!  I think that perhaps the chicken breasts I used were a bit on the small side, though.  I will definitely make this again, but I think I will perhaps cut back on the wing sauce, and add a bit more ranch dressing powder, just to give it a bit more complex flavor.  However, it was perfectly delicious made just as the recipe states.

text:
These were great! I didn't use quite as much hot sauce as called for on the original recipe.  I added 1/2 block of cream cheese (used 1/3 less fat) and it made them a little creamier.  Without these two changes this would have been way to spicy for us (and we love the taste of buffalo sauce).  Served them on mini subs and sprinkled with shredded cheddar and ranch smeared on the subs.  We had leftovers for dinner and the chicken was not as spicy as it was right after it was done cooking.  Will definitely make these again soon!  DELICIOUS!

text:
I made this yesterday for the first time. I put 6 frozen chicken breasts in the crockpot along with the recommended wing sauce and ranch seasoning pkt. It smelled wonderful cooking-just like hot wings! After the chicken was cooked I took it out and shredded it, (put in some butter) then put it back into the crockpot to reabsorb the juices and seasoning. My daughter and husband walked in from basketball and thier mouths started watering. They told me the could smell it all the way in the garage! We toasted regular buns in the oven and scooped the chicken on. It was very good, and low fat b/c of the breast meat. I think I will skip on the butter next time b/c I notice on the wing sauce bottle that butter decreases the wing sauce hotness. We will make again, over and over! Thanks for the great idea!

Now I can have my own chicken pull apart sandwich.  I've never fixed anything like this before...and my only hesitation now is the amount of salt. I used unsalted butter to help a little. Not sure if it helped the volume of salt, but I used about 12 oz of Frank's mildest buffalo wing sauce with some GATES Kansas City BBQ sauce and a splash of white wine for the marinade/slow cooker sauce.  I also added some diced bacon bits I had around.  Raw bacon would have cooked fine too. Sauteed in garlic/butter sauce some onion rings and sliced Shitake mushrooms later to put on top of the sandwich.  Very good flavor with enough spice fer sure (Gates isn't for sissy's either).

text:
This was a big hit!!! I read so many of the reviews and was debating how much wing sauce to put with the chicken. We love spicy stuff! I just happened to have about 10 ounces of Louisiana wing sauce original in the cabinet so I used that. I also added about a tablespoon of butter in the beginning with one packet of ranch. Cooked on low for about 4 hours then turned on high for about one hour then shredded the chicken and put back in the original sauce. Once shredded I put back on low for about 2 hours which was perfect. I used 2 frozen breasts and 5 tenderloins. This made a big batch!! I was so unsure to drain the chicken or not but I am glad I did not, the shredded chicken soaked up the rest of the sauce. I never did add any extra hot sauce. I also added about 1/4 block of cream cheese and a little garlic pepper. This was perfect. It was very spicy so I would never be able to use the entire bottle of Wing sauce. Thank you for a great recipe!!!!!!! Oh and I used hoagie buns, I put butter on them and a thin layer of sharp shredded cheddar and baked about 4 minutes for a toasted bun. Happy happy husband!!!

Fantastic. Served on a fresh roll with a little ranch dressing, lettuce and sliced onion. My husband was amazed, loved it. I will say, that I NEVER, EVER, EVER, cook chicken for more than 4 or 4.5 hours in the crockpot. EVER. I cooked three large breasts for 4.5 hours for this recipe and it was perfect. Anytime I cook chicken longer than that in the crockpot it comes out dry and tough.

text:
Excellent! So easy! I only had 3 large chicken breasts and 12 oz of Franks wing sauce, so I went with it and it worked out great! Added just a tad water with chicken boullion (I would estimate 4-5 Tbsp) with the 3/4 of the bottle of sauce and the dry ranch mix and it was very saucy and nice n spicy. My chicken wasn't dry at all at exactly 6 hrs. (last 1/2hr shredded chicken and let it soak up the sauce). I didn't miss the fatty fried skin at all! Tasted like a buffalo chicken sandwich you'd get in a restaurant, but it might be a tiny bit less fat/calories than the fried breast. :)  I put extra sauce and ranch dressing on top before topping with the top bun (adding the fat back in!). Provelone or Jack cheese would have been great too. Definitely will be making again! We will be having buffalo chicken pizzas this week with the leftovers! Mm. Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
"Great Cluck for your Buck!"  This was a very easy recipe!  After reading previous reviews I placed my chicken breast in the crockpot with chicken broth and Franks Wing sauce and cooked on low for about 6 hours.  Afterwards, I shredded the chicken and placed back in the crockpot with more franks sauce.  I just tasted and poured~tasted and poured~this may have helped with the salty taste previous posters reported.  Great sandwich served with french fries and cut celery and of course a great football game~GO VOLS!!!

We really liked this and it was super easy!  I put the chicken, franks sauce, and I used ranch dressing b/c I didn't have the dry mix, and cooked on low all day.  When I got home I removed the chicken, poured out the liquid (the dressing made it a little separated) and shredded the chicken, and tossed it back in the CP w/ a little more franks and ranch and let warm while I toasted the buns.  I added some mozzarella cheese b/c it's what I had on hand, and it was delish!  I can't wait to try w/ provalone!

This was delicious!I've never tried buffalo wing sauce on anything so I had no idea what to expect but I loved it. I was afraid it would be too hot for me but it wasn't at all and I even put extra on my sandwich.I used the Franks buffalo sauce and I served the sandwiches with blue cheese coleslaw.I loved the coleslaw with this and all I did was whisk 1/2 cup mayo,1/2 cup buttermilk,1 TB apple cider vinegar,2 TB sugar and 1 oz crumbled blue cheese then add a bag of coleslaw mix.I served the chicken and slaw in deli buns and everyone loved it.I would not change a thing with this recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this recipe at least twice a week for over a year. My menu changes regularly as I love to experiment with new foods, but this is one thing my family just won't do without. It is our absolute favorite meal. My husband has had me make it for ALL of his friends and family and I've gotten major good wiffey points. I've tweaked it a little over time to make it cheaper and easier, but it's still just as amazing. I use Franks Red Hot (not the buffalo sauce, but the hot sauce) and I use about 1/3 bottle - 1/2 bottle. This way the chicken isn't so saucy, it makes the bread to soggy to eat. Also, I serve it on hamburger buns, or preferably onion buns. And if you don't have a slow cooker, no problem. Cook the chicken separately, however you prefer, shred it in a pan and add ingredients (I use ranch straight from the bottle, cheaper than the powder). Throw the buns in a warm oven just long enough to get crispy and serve.... YUM! I'd rather stay in and eat this than eat out any day, even if it means doing the dishes.

text:
I couldn't believe how juicy, tender and flavorful this was. I followed the advice of other reviewers and added a bit of chicken broth at the beginning of the cook time. Back in Western New York, we don't buy bottled "wing sauce;" we mix Frank's Hot Sauce and melted butter (the more butter, the milder the sauce). I did that here, and omitted the butter added later in the recipe. Like others, I didn't have dry ranch dressing mix on hand and substituted in regular ranch dressing. It was fine, but I will try it next time with the dry mix. I didn't add more wing sauce at the end--it was more than spicy and saucy enough at that point. Very well received at the potluck to which I took it, and many people asked for the recipe.

country:
None
text:
As much as I loved the flavor of the chicken and how easy it was to put together, it's really better for pizza or a wrap. It was way too messy for sandwiches. The only change I made was to do a nice "gloop" of ranch dressing in with the buff sauce to add more moisture. My chicken came out so juicy and not dried out at all and it shredded beautifully. Also, to anyone who had the issue of dried up chicken, make sure your crock pot isn't malfunctioning. Check your user manual to see what the temp should be for "low" setting and use a thermometer to check it. If it's off then that's why your chicken dried out (it cooked too fast). Hope this helped someone!

Display Name:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good! Many said it's too salty, but I didn't think so. Others said it's too spicy. Well, buffalo wings are always spicy...often spicier than this was. If you don't like heat, this isn't for you! 

I used 5 half breasts and bathed them in about 6 oz of Moore's buffalo wing sauce and half a ranch packet. My husband loves wings and spicy foods, and he loved this, so I'm making it again tonight. The last time I made this, I used about 10 oz of the 12 oz bottle, and it was a little too saucy, so I imagine that using 17.5 oz on 4 half breasts would be way too saucy. I'm sticking with about half the Moore's bottle for now, and if it dries up, I'll add more. Easier to add than to take away! I'm leaving out the butter because this recipe already isn't very healthy. Make sure you don't over-shred the chicken. I did that the last time I made this because the chicken was so tender, and it almost became like a mush. It was still good, but the slightly chunky chicken texture shown in the picture wasn't there, and we would have preferred it, so I'm going to be more careful this time and will probably stop cooking it at 6 hours rather than 7. This recipe was too spicy for me, so I'm going to try Texas Pete's extra mild buffalo sauce the next time I make this, because I want to enjoy it as much as my husband does! Thanks for the recipe.

Very good! To cut some of the heat, I modified by adding about a cup of chicken broth and a T of BBQ sauce. It still had enough a kick to it. Like others suggested, I put the shredded meat back in the crockpot for the last hour or so. Served on lettuce wraps with a bit of bleu cheese dressing. Delish! For the kids, I served on buns with provolone. I used a 12 oz bottle of sauce and the whole packet of ranch and it wasn't terribly salty - probably depends on the type of sauce you choose.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
HUGE HIT!  I crowd sized this recipe for a group of mainly guys and it was raved about!  I used a 10lb bag of Costco chicken breasts (boneless & skinless) 2 - 12oz bottles Frank's Wings Sauce, 2 - 1oz pkgs of powdered Ranch dressing and 2 sticks of butter.  Because of the size I split the frozen breasts evenly between 2 large crockpots and put half all the ingredients in each on High for 4 hours.  I took out the breasts, skimmed the fat off the sauce and shredded the meat with forks.  I then returned it ALL to one large crock pot.  I served it on buns with extra sauce and coleslaw to put on the sandwich - amazing!  For coleslaw I used 3 - 16oz pks chopped cabbage and 1 - 25oz jar Marie's Coleslaw dressing...it was a perfect topping!

text:
Buffalo Chicken doesn't get much easier than this.  I put the ingredients in the crockpot before going to bed and we enjoyed the sandwiches for lunch the next day.  The meat was so tender and was loaded with flavor.  I was worried that they would be too runny to eat with the liquid in the bottom of the crockpot, but once I shredded the meat, it all disappeared.  I served these on shooter size buns and added bleu cheese crumbles to some of the sandwiches.  Thanks Divinesolace21 for sharing this recipe.  This would make a great sandwich for SuperBowl parties.

text:
This is one of the best dishes I have ever made.  My husband requests this several times a month, and his friends have told their wives how to find the recipe after having it at my home, because it is just so good!  I put all ingredients (except the rolls of course!) into the slow cooker for 5-6 hours, shred the chicken, and then put it in for another hour.  I serve it on toasted rolls with a splash of wing sauce on it and sometimes a little blue cheese or even shredded cheddar.  Delish!

text:
This was awesome, however I did not follow it I just used it as inspiration this was my take on it and my husband LOVED IT!: 

-I used chicken thighs instead of breast (as breast is typically too dry)
-I used one 350ml jar of buffalo wing sauce and then 1 jar of sweet onion chipotle sauce to add some depth of flavour
-I added half a large onion (rough chopped)
-I also added a few bacon slices, diced, for flavour

I cooked on high for 6 hours and it was awesome!

text:
Tender and spicy and just right for rolls.  I used Tony Roma's wing sauce which comes in a 17.5 oz bottle.  I used only about 1/3-1/2 of the bottle as it is really spicy for my taste and then added about 1/2 a cup of water or so to ensure enough liquid.  I used 1/2 a package of Uncle Dan's ranch dressing mix.  I've said this before but I think it is worth repeating....please, if a sauce or mix is being used, specifiy the brand that you are using.  We all have to make do with what we can get in our area, however, changing the brand can really change the character of the dish and I would like to try recipes for the first time with what the original recipe contributor suggests.

text:
This was amazing!!! Definitely one of my favorites. I am a sucker for Charlies buffalo chicken sandwhich, so when I saw this recipe I was very excited to try it. I too used Franks wing sauce. I added 1 12oz bottle Franks wing sauce, 1 package hidden valley dry ranch mix into the crockpot and mixed. I then added 6 frozen chicken breasts. Cooked on high for 2 hours and turned the chicken breasts over. Cooked on low for another 4 hours. When the chicken was done I removed the chicken from the liquid and shredded with the 2 tbsp of butter. I then added the desired amount of sauce left over in the pot to the shredded chicken. Served on a hamburger bun with swiss cheese and ranch dressing. It would have been yummy with lettuce and tomato too.

text:
I was in the mood for some buffalo chicken, but not wings. This was great! Both my husband and I really enjoyed it. I did 3 boneless chicken breasts, then a few boneless thighs (I tried to make sure the weight of the thighs was equal to 1 breast). I didn't have any problems with the hot sauce absorbing, though I did do it on high for a few hours vs 6-7 hours on low. I noticed the recipe calls for a 17.5 oz bottle of hot sauce and my Franks is only 12 oz, so I used the whole bottle in the crockpot and then a little bit more from another. We didn't even add the extra hot sauce at the end, we thought it was perfect as is. Oh and I did use the whole package of ranch mix. We'll keep making this! It was great with some provolone on the rolls. I thought the leftover chicken was really good on a salad too

Delicious.  Used Frank's buffalo wing sauce and at the 5 hour mark when I shredded the chicken I also added in some Frank's RedHot - Xtra Hot Sauce to give it a bit more kick.  Placed buns on a pan and sprinkled shredded nacho cheese on them and broiled them for ~1 minute to get the cheese nice and melted.

Makes amazing pizza the next day.  Used 3 cheese ranch dressing as the sauce with red onion, roasted garlic, and mushrooms.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was Yummy! Everybody loved it! I was afraid to make it after some of the negative reviews, but I'm glad I did. I took about 6 chicken breast and put some chicken broth inside the slow cooker and cooked that for about two and a half hours on high. Then I drained the broth, shredded the chicken, and threw in the salad dressing mix, and a 12 fl oz bottle of the Frank's Buffalo Sauce (they didn't have the big one at the store) and mixed everything together. I cooked for another 30 minutes and it turned out perfect. I think the key is to add the sauce during the end of cooking so it doesn't dry out. I even forgot the butter! I served it with slider buns with ranch dressing, and some chopped celery for a nice crunch.

text:
Very Yummy and easy!  However be careful when buying your sauce. As others I used the Franks Red Hot Wing Sauce.  Do not confuse this with the regular Franks Red Hot otherwise your dish will be super hot!  The bottle must say Franks Red Hot Wing Sauce and it has plenty of kick on its own.  Topping your sandwiches with blue cheese dressing or blue cheese crumbles is delicious and its cuts the heat.

These were really good & I thought it was a great idea for buffalo chicken. My only complaints were that it was a little too wet than I would've liked, but that may have been my fault for not following the instructions completely..I put everything in the slow cooker all at once! Next time I may try to make my own wing sauce so I can control the heat. And will definitely only put in half the amount of sauce in the beginning as stated in the recipe.

country:
None
text:
Super easy & really tasty. Turned out like Sloppy Buffaloes or Pulled Chicken, moist and delicious.  Substitutions: 1/4 pkt of dry ranch, about 1/2 cup blue cheese dressing plus I rinsed buffalo sauce bottle with water and added that water to mix.  About 1c. water total and I think that was key.  Chicken was fresh, not frozen so 4 hrs. on low was perfect.  Pulled apart with 2 forks and it fell apart. Cont'd on low for another 30 min.  Good stuff!  Make double and freeze remainder or leftovers can be made into  Buffalo Nachos, Enchiladas or baked into a Buffalo Chicken Dip by adding some cream cheese.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4284648.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really easy recipe to follow with just a few ingredients. The only think I added was a 1/2 cup of chicken stock. I used Frank's Buffalo Wing sauce and it was somewhat spicy. That was OK since we all like spicy. If you don't like spicy just look for a mild Buffalo Wing Sauce. I cooked it at a low setting for 3.5 hours shredded it and returned it to the crock pot and let it simmer in the juices. I simply shredded the chicken breasts with a knife and fork. A few reviewers commented their chicken breasts were dry but just make sure you cook it on low, and there is enough sauce too. My buffalo chicken did not come out dry at all Another reviewer compared the shredded chicken to tuna. It sounds like they used a processor to shred the chicken. Simply use a knife and fork and it will not shred like tuna! My whole family loves this recipe and asks for it over and over again!

Made it  yesterday. I used 3 large chicken breast halves and it was plenty! 5 sandwiches, someone ate half of a breast as is, plus some leftovers! I also used the whole packet of ranch mix (why save a half of packet?) And threw the butter and sprinkled some celery seed in with it all. text:
I have two problems with this recipe.  First the amount of buffalo wing sauce is way too much IMO.  After shredding the chicken I poured off the liquid and added some back to the chicken, but probably only used about half of it.  Had I used the entire amount, this would have been way too wet.  I also thought the cooking time was way too long, at least for my slow cooker.  My chicken was perfectly done in 4 hours on low.  We werent huge fans of this.  Maybe were just not buffalo wing fans.  But that is no fault of the recipe.  Four stars for the amount of sauce and cooking time.  I used this to make Buffalo Chicken and Ranch Wraps, also on this site.

text:
We really liked this a lot.  I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs and cooked them for about 6 hours on low.  I thickened the sauce with a little cornstarch slurry at the end of the cook time.  It tastes good without the butter, but adding the butter gives the sauce a nice silky texture.

text:
I made this tonight for dinner and it was a huge hit.  I was short on time so cooked it in a big frying pan with a lid and it turned out great! I had only glanced at the recipe so inadvertently mixed up a couple of things - I cooked the chicken in the butter and ranch mix and then added the bottle of hot sauce.  Simmered on low for about an hour and then shredded the chicken. We made it into wraps with cheese, tomato and lettuce.  The tomato helped cut the heat of it for the wimpier member of our family (me).  I had the hot sauce sweats for about an hour after but that just added to the greatness of it.  I've already decided to use some of the leftovers in the morning with a poached egg, diced tomato and lettuce on a corn tortilla.

text:
Let me just say I am an amateur cook. I dont usually know what I'm doing but manage to pull things off and 5 stars was NOT enough for this. it was so good. I tweeked things a bit. We used boneless thighs, 3 tablespoons of butter, 1 bottle of texas pete buffalo sauce the hidden valley ranch mix, and I added a cup of water. I mixed all ingredients in the crock pot and cooked it all stirring occasionally for about 7 hrs. The chicken was shredded on its own by that time. put it on soft sesame hoagie buns with a splash of buffalo sauce and ranch it was so delicious! However you tweek it, I'm sure it will be delicious! Good luck!

So delicious!! I left out the step with the butter to make it a bit healthier and I didnt feel like I was missing anything! I placed the chicken back in the crockpot for about 30 mins after shredding to re-absorb some of the sauce, rather than using the rest in the bottle (so much sauce in the pot I felt like it would be a waste!) I also made a topping for the sandwiches - I mixed ranch dressing, blue cheese crumbles, and diced celery, and it was AMAZING on top of the sandwiches!  Definitely messy but so worth it and my husband can't wait for me to make this again!

Display Name:
Laura Tucker
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/279647.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Giving this 5 stars on my husband's behalf.  This recipe is super easy to make and is very flexible on amounts and ingredients - I just threw two chicken breasts, dumped enough hot sauce in so it was almost covering the chicken (probably 1 - 1 1/2 cups), threw in 1-2 T of butter (I added the butter at the beginning) and a little ranch dressing (the liquid dressing, since I didn't have any packets on hand), and turned on the machine.  I cooked it on high for a couple of hours, shredded the chicken with two forks, and cooked it on low for a couple more hours, although it probably could have been done sooner.  I've made this a few times and knew that I didn't want leftover liquid, so I added some corn starch for the last hour or so to thicken everything up.  Great served on buns with blue cheese crumbles or ranch dressing, with carrot sticks or celery on the side.  My husband's favorite!

text:
This was pretty good! My boyfriend realy loved it! We used Sweet Baby Rays Buffalo sauce, and it was pretty spicey (and we love spicey!) but it was alittle TOO spicey...ahhh wheres my burts bees!?!?! I think next time we will try it with Hooters Sauce which I know is available at Walmart so hopefully it wont be as intense. I pre-shredded the chicken at the 4 hr mark into cooking so that all the chicken was nice and coated and marinated not just the outter parts and let it cook anouther hr. It was perfectly juicy. Also, we did this on tortillas with lettuce and fresh blue cheese crumbles! DELISH!

text:
This is a great 2 dish meal. I slowed cooked the chicken in chicken  broth and when ready to shred I left just a touch of broth in the bottom and then added the buffalo sauce and ranch. I also added just a touch of white sugar to help tone down the tang in the sauce. (I was careful not to add too much sugar so I wouldn't end up with a confused dish) We ate these with maple flavored baked beans and slaw. I then used the leftovers to make a ranch & buffalo chicken pizza. I sauteed sweet onions and added bacon and used colby jack cheese. So good! Everybody loved both recipes!

country:
None
text:
Wow.  This recipe definitely answers my craving for buffalo chicken.  I had cooked some chicken breasts in the crock pot and was undecided as to what to do with them when I came across this recipe. Since me chicken was already cooked, I shredded it and mixed together Frank's Wing Sauce with some bottled ranch dressing.  I poured it over the chicken and put back in the fridge for a few hours.  When it was time to eat, I simply reheated it and served on fresh ciabatta rolls.  What's nice about this recipe is that you can calm it down a bit by adding more ranch,for those who can't tolerate the heat.  Definitely a keeper!

This could be better but I think the whole point of this recipe is the simpleness.  I would change it up:
1 pound boneless, skinless chicken thighs, cut into 1 1/2 inch pieces
coarse salt and ground pepper
1 pound boneless skinless chicken breasts, cut into 1 1/2 inch pieces
1 package frozen seasoning blend - onion, celery, peppers, etc.
3 garlic cloves
1 can (28 oz) diced tomatoes
1/4 cup franks hot wing sauce
3 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce
2 tablespoon yellow mustard
1 tablespoon honey

This was excellent - this was what I would consider medium spicy like at buffalo wild wings or chili's boneless wings - way yummy way easy. BarrBelle

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is great made as a wrap too or on a bed of shredded lettuce.  I used the dry ranch dressing mix from this site, slightly modified (add 1 tsp dill and 1/2 cup dry buttermilk powder then use 2-3 Tbs. of the resulting mix) - it's gluten free and works well, and Frank's Original Hot Sauce.  With the left overs (just hubby and I were eating) I made a chicken tortilla soup adding 1 chopped onion, 1-2 cloves garlic, 1 pint tomatoes, 2 cups whole kernel corn, 2 cups chicken broth, a pinch of oregano , about 1/4 cup chopped cilantro and juice of one lime (or lemon).  Serve over tortilla chips/strips with shredded cheese.  Top with more cilantro and some chopped avacado.  Pretty and delicious.  Can also add black beans.  So you can get several dinners from this start!

This was great but I did make a few tweaks/additions that came out great. I did half breast meat half boneless skinless thigh meat to add flavor and tenderness. I also used Franks Red hot for the sauce. I toasted the rolls with crumbled blue cheese to melt a little, then piled on the shredded chicken. I also added some diced fresh crisp celery on top. It literally tasted like the best buffalo wings ever on a sandwich with the celery and blue cheese added in! Flavor explosion!

I made about a triple batch of this for a holiday potluck at my office. It was a nice change of pace from the traditional potluck items (meatballs, chili, etc). It didn't receive any specific rave reviews, but a good portion of it was eaten, so I'll take that as a compliment. It stayed moist after several hours (well above the recommended cook time). I think it was due to my packing my slowcooker to the brim with chicken. On the whole, a pretty easy recipe. Just make sure to serve it with a really good quality kaiser roll...makes all the difference.

My absolute favorite recipe!  This is so easy I make almost once a week, just throw in 4 frozen chicken breast with 1 packet ranch and about  bottle of Franks Wing Sauce.  I slow cook for about 7 to 8 hours, then it shreds super easy, no need for the butter IMO.  I serve on Kaiser rolls with sliced red onion, bleu cheese dressing & mozzarella cheese. So good!  I have also used the leftovers for the Buffalo Style Chicken Pizza recipe on this site and thats super good also.

region:

country:
None
text:
What a fabulous idea, especially those of us who LOVE "buffalo chicken anything" and like to use their slow cooker as often as possible!  This was a hit, altho recipe was heavily modified.  I coated the chicken breasts in the ranch salad dressing seasoning.  Then i made my homemade version of buffalo sauce which is the one with Franks RedHot, butter, garlic powder, white wine, parsley, and a dash of white pepper.  I coated the chicken with this and honestly, this dish could have been done in 3 hours.  It was in about 5.5 hrs and i had to remove because it started to burn. However, I will say it is most likely my slow cooker, it is very hot and cooks food too fastAnyway i pulled the chicken apart AND WE had it on hoagie rolls from a deli we love, and he put a few spurts of ranch on his and i used blue cheese crumbles.  I also sliced carrot sticks and celery sticks for a side instead of the usual fries, since the chicken itself looks to be heavily fattening. My husband and I both ate it all and LOVED it!  Thanks for this recipe.

region:

country:
None
text:
I used two whole frozen chicken breasts and half a bottle of Frank's Red Hot sauce mixed that with half a package of the dry Ranch and threw it in the crockpot.  I put it on low for 8 hours (then it switches to keep warm).  When I got home I pulled the chicken out and shredded (it was a little dry) so I added the rest of the Frank's and threw it back in the pot and kept on keep warm for about 2 hours.  I absolutely loved it - just enough kick for me.  However, my boyfriend said it was way to spicy for him, so maybe next time I'll stick with half a bottle and add extra on just my sandwich.  Overall I really enjoyed it - and it was easy!

text:
This was awesome! I used 6 large frozen chicken breasts and let them cook in about 2/3 of the sauce and a whole packet of the dry ranch for 5 hours. Then I drained most of the liquid, shredded the chicken (which fell apart perfectly) and put back in slow cooker with the rest of the sauce for 2 hours. This was soooo good! A keeper and SO EASY recipe.

text:
I recently made this for a large group of hungry guys.  I was a little skeptical (it seems almost too simple!).  Needless to say, they ate two sandwiches a piece, and after I ran out, they were all begging for the recipe.  I almost wish is was harder to make so I looked better! : )  I changed it slightly--I cooked the chicken for 5 hours on low, then I shredded it and then I placed it back in the slow cooker for an hour or so just to let all the flavors penetrate the whole chicken breast.  I served it with the sauce, blue cheese, and ranch on the side and the boys went CRAZY for it!  Thanks for the great (and easy) recipe!

text:
We enjoyed this very much. Since we're not all fans of spicy food, I used a bottle of Frank's sweet and spicy buffalo wing sauce. Perfect amount of heat. I used bone-in chicken breasts, removed from the bone when tender, and put the shredded meat back in the crockpot for a bit to soak up the sauce. I drizzled ranch dressing on top of each (I'll try bleu cheese dressing next time)- the cool creaminess was a perfect foil to the spicy heat of the sauce. So easy to make, and quite tasty!

This was a big hit with my husband!  He insists that I make this for our annual Superbowl Party. STARDUST_331

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/40384.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really good!!!  I am always skeptical about slow cooker chicken stuff because white meat tends to dry out the longer you cook it, opposite of all other meats.  I only used 12 oz wing sauce and 3 big chicken breasts (I think almost 1 3/4 pounds) and didn't need to add any more sauce before eating, because there was plenty left.  This made enough for 6 sandwiches.  Served this with 'Absolutely the BEST Rich and Creamy Blue Cheese Dressing' on this site.  I don't know if the chicken needed to be frozen, but in my paranoia over ending up with dry chicken, I bought and froze the chicken.  It turned out really moist so I'm not messing with this one!  I shredded it after 4 hours and cooked it for 1 more, and it was great.  Tossed it back into the sauce and served it like that.

text:
I was in the mood for Buffalo Chicken and decided upon this recipe. In the slow cooker I put in a couple frozen breasts (still frozen) and only the buffalo sauce.  After 6 hours it was fall-apart tender, I couldn't even pick it up with a fork without it shredding itself..  Sometimes slow cooked breast meat seems tough to me, but that didn't happen today.  I didn't use a ranch packet or butter at all but instead made up a homemade creamy peppercorn dressing.  Served on a kaiser roll with that creamy dressing, chopped celery and blue cheese crumbles. I may or may not have topped with a bit more of the buffalo sauce.  The celery added a really nice crunch that this sandwich needs.  Out-fricking-Standing.

text:
Yep, I will be making this again!  Super easy weeknight meal and I made enough to freeze for an even easier meal at a later date.   I used Frank's Red Hot Wing Suace (buffalo flavor) and it wasn't spicy at all - next time I will look for a higher heat variety.  Grilled both hoagie buns and onion rolls then added melted Monterey Jack to each - consensus was onion rolls next time. My son and husband added tomatoes and onions to theirs too. I generally dislike crockpot cooking since most everything seems like dried out, over cooked meat that all taste the same.  This one is helping me change my mind!

text:
This was a huge hit with my boyfriend and his friends! However, I definitely did not need the full 7.5 hours to cook this thing. I started off by putting my slow cooker on high for 3.5 hours. Then I separated the chicken or fork the chicken, then place slow cooker on low and I let it sit for only another 1.5 hours before it was ready to eat! We paired it with blue cheese sauce on the side and sourdough bread that was super soft and went great with it. And finally, we added some cilantro!! If you run out of bread like we did, using romaine lettuce just for wraps are a sweet idea and makes it super refreshing!!

text:
The recipe I made was good, but I made a lot of changes. My local grocery doesn't carry Frank's Red Hot, so I substituted. In it's place I put 3/4 a bottle of Lousiana hot sauce, three tablespoons of butter, and went on with the recipe (mostly) as planned. My slow cooker is stuck on High, as it has been since 2003 when five year old me tore the knob off. So it only took two hours. When cooked through I shredded it, wrapped it in a tortilla, and added ranch on top. It was delicious, but most definitely not the same as the recipe above. I'm mostly posting this review as an easy substitution.

text:
I LOVED this recipe!! I'm giving it 5 stars, but I'll mention that I used my own homemade buffalo sauce and homemade ranch seasoning mix, so I wouldn't know exactly how this would taste with store-bought stuff. I also cut the recipe in half, so the chicken was perfectly done after only 5 hours on low. Not dry at all! I shredded the chicken in the crockpot with all the juices, and mixed it all together. Perfection! I also did not add extra buffalo sauce at the end, because the flavor was AWESOME and I didn't want to drown it in too much sauce. The method I used was exactly the same as the recipe though, and the final result was phenomenal!!  I will definitely be putting this in regular rotation, especially for my husband's lunches! Thank you for a delicious and easy recipe!

These were very good.  I don't know if adding the ranch mix did anything for flavor. I used a 12 oz. bottle of Franks buffalo wing sauce. I cooked 4 large breasts on high for 4 hours. It was perfect. It was not too hot.

I've now cooked this countless times, and its phenomenal. Easy and delicious, impossible to screw up. Try substituting various other sauces for a portion of the franks; we've had nothing but tasty experiments with this. My favorite is a 1/4 chipotle barbecue in place of 1/4 of the franks - doesnt detract from the flavor but turns down the spice a notch and adds smoky deliciousness.

country:
None
text:
Don't know if I should be rating this recipe seeing as how I made 1 huge change. I was unable to find a bottle of mild buffalo sauce (if such a thing exists) so I added a bottle of Frank's Sweet Chilli sauce instead. I followed all of the other directions and this came out amazing. I served it on kaiser rolls with pickle chips, sweet potato fries and a garlic aioli sauce for dipping. The sauce went great with the sandwiches. My 8-year-old said this was the best meal ever and my 16-month-old gobbled it up. 5 Hours on low was enough time to cook the chicken and after I shredded it I returned it to the slow cooker for another 30 minutes to absorb all of the sauce that was swimming around in the pot. I will definitely make this again.

text:
This was so easy to get together which was a huge help on a busy morning.  I loved the flavor of the sauce although it is a tad salty.  The chicken fell apart, but, was incredibly dry.   I should have trusted my instincts and known not to cook boneless breasts for 6-7 hours.    I will make this again, although, next time reduce the time or just put it in a dutch oven and bake.  I am rating based on the taste of the recipe, but, the timing was off.

text:
Okay, I have to confess something:  I made this recipe EXACTLY as written!  And it was great!  I get so irritated when everyone chimes in with "oh, but I changed the buffalo for barbecue sauce".  

I didn't have high hopes as I've done white meat in the slow cooker before, and have done it too long I guess because it came out chalky.  This did not, and I'm glad to have a meal I can quickly prep in the morning and come home at night and it's ready to go.  I know a lot of slow cooker recipes are that, but they're also fatty and caloric.  I'm into fitness and eating clean and this one is great.  What's leaner than chicken breast?

So, kudos to devinesolace - thanks for a keeper.

text:
I have made this recipe time and time again.  It is a staple for football parties and office pot lucks. Everyone raves about it and I am always asked for the recipe.  Some people just eat the chicken on it's own; I will have hoagie rolls or potato rolls on the side to use. I also like to put out the prepackaged slaw from the produce section with ranch dressing for those who prefer to cool down the heat a bit. It is super simple and requires very little hands on time. My best advice is to use a wing sauce that you enjoy.

I make this recipe frequently. I use half chicken breasts and half thighs, and just pick out the bones and joints at the end of cooking. I also add a couple cloves of minced garlic to the crock pot. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was pretty good, I used franks Red hot chicken wing sauce which is pretty mild compared to regular franks red hot. I added a cup of chicken broth mixed with the hot sauce, added some diced onion and celery drizzled the chicken with EVOO, used 6 chicken breasts and put the butter in at the beginning of the cooking. Chicken shredded easily after about 6 hours. I kept the shredded chicken in the liquid for about another 30 min to soak up the juice.  Served it on crusty chabatta bread with some extra hot sauce. I plan on trying the left overs in a wrap as other reviewers suggested.  I made the blue cheese coleslaw from this site and did not like that at all.

text:
This is one of my husband's favorite things that I make.  Before adding the wing sauce,  I pour it into a container and mix the whole packet of ranch seasoning.  I also add 2 cloves minced garlic.  Then pour over 4 chicken breasts.  Cook on low 4-5 hrs, shred, add butter, then let cook on low for another 30-45 min.  Serve on toasted hoagie rolls with melted american cheese, blue cheese dressing.  YUM!

text:
These are scrumptious!! I did make a couple of changes. I only used a half cup of hot wing sauce and added a half cup of water to it in my measuring cup and mixed in the ranch dressing. I only had the "thick" version of the wing sauce on hand. But it worked out well because I still had sauce left to add to the sandwich once it was built. Super yummy! Even my 4 year-old who doesn't like spicy liked these, I just put ranch on her sandwich instead of more wing sauce. Wonderful recipe, versatile to please every member of your family, even the picky ones! ;-)

text:
I took this to a potluck at work. Everyone loved it, there was none left and everyone wanted recipe. It was not too salty or spicy ( I should have taken some regular hot sauce for the people who wanted more heat) as some of the reviewers mentioned. I did add celery and onions to the bottom of pot and marinade the chicken with onion and garlic powder, pepper, a little creole seasoning, about a tablespoon of rice wine vinegar, a couple tablespoons of evoo for at least an hour. I will definitely be making this 1 of my fave crockpot meals.

region:

country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe over a dozen times and it always gets rave reviews.  I use 6+ chicken breasts in a crockpot and keep the rest of the recipe the same.  I made 2 crockpots of this recipe for my son's graduation & I am not exaggerating when I tell you that his friends finished both crockpots in 30 minutes.  I use slider rolls and make my own blue cheese dressing for topping. If you do have left overs, you can always use tortillas & shredded cheese & lettuce for Buffalo Chicken wraps. I have also filled large wonton wrappers with the chicken and cheese & folded into a triangle & deep fried! Possibly one of the best crock pot recipes of all time!!!

This recipe was great! I did modify it a bit because I like a kick but not too much. I used a half bottle of Franks Hot Sauce and 1/4 cup of chicken broth. I wanted my kids to be able to eat it too. Instead of the bread I used a tortilla and threw some lettuce, tomatoes and sour cream. It was a hit at my house.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very delicious! Used thigh and breast fresh chicken (~ 1 lb of each), 8 oz Frank's Red Hot "Wings - Buffalo" Sauce (if you choose to use more sauce, be aware the chicken might get soupy), omitted dry Ranch dsg, did put the (real) butter in, also added 1/3 cup lowfat cream cheese to mellow the heat (it doesn't curdle if you cook on LOW). 4 Qt crock, on Low 5 hrs - then removed lid and stirred chicken with fork, the chicken shreds itself and sauce mixes in nicely. Replaced lid, cooked 1 hr more.  Melts in your mouth.  Great with cheddar cheese and ranch dressing.  We will be eating this weekly!

text:
Holy cow! I tried this recipe for the first time to serve to our guests on NY Eve - they LOVED it! Just a few very minor changes/additions: I used chicken tenderloins and boneless/skinless thighs for added flavor. I also added a bit of chicken broth in the beginning since I did read others comments on their chicken drying out after a few hours. Lastly, I removed some of the sauce and blended in a block of softened cream cheese right before it was ready to serve. So creamy and good served over sourdough rolls. Thanks for sharing such a great (and simple) recipe!

text:
Ok well I forgot to take everything out of the freezer until I got home at 3:00pm I have been wanting to make theese for a few weeks now. So my chicken was frozen 3 hours before dinner. I was determined to make theese so I poached my frozen chicken in chicken broth and water for about 20 minutes. They were pretty much cooked when I took them out of the pan. I cut them up and put them in the crock pot with franks wing sauce and a pkg of hidden valley ranch, cooked them on high for 1 hour, then broke them up/shredded them took a 12 pack of slider buns put those on a foil lined cookie sheet put the chicken mixture on them, topped them with some provalone cheese sprayed the top of the buns with butter flavoed cooking spray covered them with foil and baked them at 425 for 10 minutes, top shelf...... went with the temp I had to cook the tater tots at. 12 sliders, 3 people, I got 1 hubby and son loved them. Can't wait to do them all the way in the crockpot. I think they will be even better that way!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night and it was great.  I cooked three large chicken breasts, a full 12 oz bottle of Franks RedHot Wings Sauce.  I used the Buffalo flavor, not the Hot Buffalo flavor.  The regular buffalo flavor has plenty of heat for us although both are good.  I also added about 3/4 cup of chicken broth.  I cooked this on high for a little over three hours and then shredded the chicken and added the butter.  There was still plenty of sauce, so I didn't add anymore.  I let it go for another hour or so.  I toasted up hoagie rolls, put the chicken mixture on there, topped with some crumbled blue cheese, and a slice of Provolone cheese.  I put that under the broiler for just a short time to melt the cheese, then topped with some shredded lettuce.  It was fabulous!  My husband loved it too, in fact instead of making a second sandwich he just ate a bowl of the chicken and said how much he liked it.  I am making the buffalo chicken pizza tonight with the little leftovers we have.

text:
Was not to my liking. There really is no use in wasting your Buffalo Sauce and Ranch Dressing in the Crock Pot. I would use chicken stock (Without Ranch) and then shred Chicken and remove all liquid, otherwise runny and messy. Put Chicken back in Crock Pot with Buffalo Sauce ( I would add fresh chopped Jalapeno/Serrano and/or Habenero Peppers) and heat for a short time. Otherwise this was rather bland and not hot enough for me.

text:
I love this recipe! I have modified it a bit. I make my own buffalo sauce  by using Franks red hot and butter wisk together. That way you can control how spicy you want it. I cook the chicken on high about 4 hours with just a splash of broth, then shred the chicken, then add my buffalo sauce and a bit of ranch powder in, mix and let it cook about 2 hours on low. I toast the rolls and serve with celery and blue cheese dressing on the side. There is never any left! My whole family loves it!

text:
This recipe turned out better than I thought it would.  I used 3 chicken breasts and about 4 thighs.  I couldn't find Franks Red Hot, so I used Crystal's Wing Sauce.  One bottle of the regular wing sauce (12oz) and about 1/4 of the extra hot.  Used a full pack of Ranch Dressing Mix.  Shredded the meat, returned it to the crock and let it go for another hour or so.  Put meat on a toasted Cibatta roll and added a little blue cheese dressing.  Served with coleslaw.  Turned out with just the right about of spice.  Definitely will make this again.

text:
We loved this recipe, even though I made it without ranch! My husband doesn't like it, so I made the dish with about 1.3 lbs of chicken tenderloins, and a 12 oz. bottle of Hot wing sauce from BWW. Spicy! I had it on a low setting for about 2 1/2 hours, then I shredded the chicken, added in the 2 Tbsp of butter, and let it sit on low for another 1 1/2 hrs. Didn't add more sauce, since the 12 oz. was sufficient for the amount of chicken I had. Served it on buttered, toasted sandwich rolls with mozzarella cheese on top. Delicious - thanks for the idea!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good but I would make changes next time.  

Pros: Easy to make and good
Cons:   Very salty if you follow the recipe

Since some of the other reviewers commented this is very salty I used half the recommendation on the ranch dressing since that's salty as well. It was still too salty for my taste and next time, I'll make my own wing sauce to control the salt level.

Overall, I did enjoy it and will make again.  I don't like people reviewing recipes with their own versions but I'll be guilty of that here.  

I made smaller portion - cooked 2 frozen chicken breasts, used a little less of the dry ranch dressing, cooked on high for 5 hours, and skipped the butter since that's already in the wing sauce.  It was shredding it by pressing each chicken piecs with a potato masher (works perfectly with no work)!

I served it on a toasted hoagie roll with provolone and topped it with cole slaw (made with pre-packaged slaw cabbage mix and tossed with blue cheese dressing), and of course carrot and celery sticks on a side.

text:
Yummy - Made this for my daughter's Halloween Party last night in my triple crock pot (along with Pulled BBQ Pork - my own recipe - and just frozen meatballs w/ a good jarred marinara and peppers and onions) - Everyone loved it (college age kids), but it ended up pretty wet, so I took the lid off the crock for probably a good hour with it on high to cook out some of the water - I used 5 large breasts (almost 4 lbs) and ended up adding more Frank's Hot Buffalo Wing Sauce and stirring it in - served with Martin's Whole Wheat Potato Slider Rolls - they're slightly sweet, which I think goes well with the hot buffalo chicken - also had additional hot sauce, crumbled bleu cheese, cheddar and bleu cheese dressing available as toppings for them - I also forgot to add the butter, but nobody seemed to notice or care - Love Buffalo anything, so I'll probably make again, but I think it'd be even better braised in a dutch oven :)

text:
Very good. I add something to the cooking method though. Nix the butter at the end (not needed except to add more calories no one wants), and after you shred the chicken, bake in the oven in a casserole dish for 20 min at 350 degrees. This bakes in the sauce better. You can look and gauge how much sauce you want to add. I use Frank's buffalo sauce - like everyone else ;)

text:
this was the first slow cooker recipe i tried, and i am really disappointed! it was salty, and i didn't use nearly as much buffalo sauce (Frank's brand) nor dried ranch dressing (Hidden Valley) as was called for. the chicken turned out moist and broke apart perfectly, but the resulting flavor was so salty and vinegary that it was totally inedible to both me and my husband. i would not make this recipe again without some serious modifications. i was recommended this recipe by a friend, and she loved it, though, so it must appeal to some people.

Great! I made a mistake the first time I made these and bought the hotter version of the Franks Red Hot Buffalo sauce (I didnt realize there were different levels of the Buffalo one)... we all love spicy food, but this was so spicy that we couldnt even stomach it! text:
I think I left the chicken in a little too long because it was slightly mushy.  Still, it tasted great.  It was hot enough to leave my nose running for awhile.  I did put the chicken on round rolls, but it was too messy to pick up, and I had to eat it with a fork.

I made it again with 3 large fresh breasts.  After 4 1/2 hours it was ready to shred, so I shredded it best I could and let it soak for another hour.  This time put it on sub rolls and added coleslaw.  Fantastic!  I plan on making this for a Superbowl party, putting it on sub rolls and adding lettuce, tomato, and blue cheese. Tastes just like wings but so much easier to make!

Also, Franks makes a cayenne pepper sauce.  After shredding, I added a little of this since I like it pretty spicy.

text:
Very delicious!  I added 4 frozen chicken breasts to the crockpot and used about 3/4 of a bottle of a 16 oz bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's Buffalo Sauce and 1/2 of a package of the 1 oz pkg of dry ranch dressing mix.  I cooked them on low for 4 hours and then added 2 tablespoons of margarine, shredded the meat and let it cook for another hour in the sauce.  I toasted hamburger buns with a little butter and put the chicken on them with ranch dressing and they were delicious!  My 13 year old loved them and I am curious to see if my 18 year old will because he is a pickier eater.  He loves buffalo wings but I am unsure if he will like this recipe.

text:
This was great. My husband loved it. I made a few adjustments. I used 4 boneless, skinless thighs. I only added about 6 oz. of Frank's Hot Wing Sauce, but I also added about 4 oz. of Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ Sauce to cut the heat. I also added about 4 oz. of water. I cooked for 4 hours. I used the extra ranch mix to make roasted ranch potatoes.

country:
None
text:
This was fantastic! I used 4 chicken breasts, one 12 oz. bottle of Anchor Bar wing sauce, Medium (the inventor of the wings here in Buffalo), one .4 oz packet of Hidden Valley Buttermilk Ranch dressing mix. Mine was super moist, so I didnt add the butter. We topped ours with extra wing sauce from a second bottle, and I added some chopped up celery to my sandwiches for some extra crunch. These were a huge hit for my and my boyfriend, and it made great sandwiches all week! This recipe is a MUST for anyone who likes Buffalo-style chicken flavors and it makes your whole house smell like wings!

text:
This recipe was delish. I threw four frozen chicken breasts in the crockpot with the sauce/dressing and it so easily pulled apart with two forks the next morning.  I brushed the hoagie rolls with butter and sprinkled with garlic salt before toasting in the oven,  I then put the chicken on the hoagies, topped with shredded cheese and returned to the oven just to melt the cheese. Topped with pickles and blue cheese dressing...YUMM...will be making this many times over.

text:
Delicous!! I used sweet baby rays buffalo sauce and hidden valley ranch packet.  With the advice of another user I let the chicken cook for 5 hrs, shredded, added the butter and put back in the slow cooker for another hour or so to let the chicken absorb the sauce.  I think the butter really helped tone down the heat so dont skip it! Served it on toasted hoagie buns with melted provolone cheese and a splash of ranch.  Hubby and I loved this recipe :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Our entire family loves this recipe. The first time I made it, I followed the recipe exactly (3/4 of wing sauce which is about 12 oz) and added the rest of the bottle after shredding. A little too wet.  The last 2 times I made this recipe I mixed 12 oz of Franks Buffalo Wing sauce with 1/2 pack of dry ranch and an entire 3 lb pkg of frozen chicken breast I bought on sale. Before I put on the lid, I made sure all the pieces were covered with sauce. I slow cooked 6 to 7 hours on a higher setting.  Removed the chicken, added the butter to the sauce in the cooker, shredded the meat and put everything back in to slow cooker. No additional sauce needed unless you want it spicer! We are a family of 4 so plenty of leftovers for my teenage boys to warm up. Also - top with crumbled bleu cheese - yummm!

text:
Wow!!  This recipe was amazing!!  I was running short on time, so I had to play with the time and the temp a little.  I added the whole bottle of wing sauce in the beginning along with the whole Ranch packet.  I let the chicken cook on high for three hours, then shredded it and placed it back into the sauce and let it cook for an additional hour.  I also added 1/8 tsp of cornstarch to thicken up the sauce just a bit.  This was a huge hit last night!!  A little Bleu Cheese on top complimented it perfectly.  This is definitely a keeper!!

text:
Oh mama!!  I am a sucker for a certain taste in buffalo chicken, and this one nails it!  The tangyness, the spicyness, but also the mellowing flavour of the ranch... it all comes together in this recipe, and it's SO EASY!  Tried it for the first time last week, only change I made was the cooking process... I cooked it for about 4 1/2 hours, then shredded the chicken and added the butter, then back in the crock pot for another hour or so.  Delicious!  Had it for lunch sandwiches all week... kaiser bun, lettuce, mozza cheese, and a healthy scoop of the shredded chicken.    Would also be good simply eaten by itself as sliced chicken, or on pizza.

I have made this several times for my friends and they love it. I simmer the chicken in vegetable broth in the slow cooker until the meat falls apart when I shred it. I put the shredded chicken in a bowl and I stir in Frank's Buffalo sauce to taste. I don't bother with the ranch seasoning, although it might add extra flavor. This was excellent. My chicken breasts were frozen and I needed to speed up cooking time, so I cooked for 2 hours on high with chicken stock.  Then I drained stock and added recipe ingredients. text:
Oh my heavens....yummm!  I was nervous with some of the negative reviews as I did not have a backup plan for dinner.  I did switch some things up based on some of the reviews and my instinct.  I put the chicken (fresh not frozen) in the crockpot in 2 cups chicken broth for 4 hours.  I drained and shredded the chicken and returned it to the pot with 8 oz of wing sauce for another hour and half or so.  It was perfect!  Not to hot, not too wet, not at all vinegary.  If you like wings you would love this.  I served it on a roll with extra wing sauce at the table, blue cheese dressing and a salad on the side.  It felt like a reasonable healthy indulgence.

I really love buffalo wings and pulled pork, but I definitely do not recommend following this recipie to the T.  I used almost a full 2 pounds of chicken breast tenderloins for this, and half of the hot sauce it calls for. I did use 1/2 of a package of Hidden Valley Ranch dressing mix. Next time I am going to try just cooking the chicken and adding the sauce to my taste, probably just going to use some ranch dressing too.  Way too much sodium in the hot sauce and ranch seasoning.

text:
This was good, but based on most of the reviews, I guess I thought it would be great.  I used a cup or so of chicken broth, and only half a bottle of wing sauce and I added the butter at the beginning.  also added some bottled ranch dressing so it wouldn't be too salty as the package dressing tend to be very salty.  Got home, shredded and added a little more sauce and let it simmer for 45 minutes. Toasted some kaiser rolls on the stove and added some more dressing onto the sandwich.  It really does absorb much more of the flavor after it's shredded. Like I said, this was pretty good, but I was expecting more.  Will make again from time to time.

Hubby loved this so much, he said i can make this whenever I want! toasted hoagie buns and put provolone cheese on while toasting, also I put in two, well, glops of sour cream into chicken mixture to tone it down just a little, as I knew the kids wouldnt like it too spicy. I am not a big fan of buff. wings, but I actually liked this. And talk about EASYYYYY!. I did do as another reviewer suggested, and I shredded the chicken about 1.5 hours before it was to be served, it soaked up the sauce much better that way.

Jessica

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good base recipe, but needed some tweaking.  These are our KID FRIENDLY, LOW SODIUM tweaks:  We mixed 3/4 cup Frank's Red Hot Wing sauce, 1/4 water, and 1 tbsp. of Ranch seasoning.  I coated the chicken in garlic powder and black pepper too and poured the sauce mixture in with chicken.    Cooked all day (8-9 hours) on low; with mostly frozen chicken though.  Removed chicken and poured sauce out of slow cooker.  Added chicken back in and slow added sauce back until it was to the consistency I liked.  The chicken was a little dry on it's own and the mush factor was there, but it was still good.    I used some of the Ranch seasoning to make a Ranch coleslaw to top the sandwiches (slaw mix, mayo, milk and Ranch seasoning), YUM!  We used Muenster cheese too.  My husband and I added more wing sauce on ours, but our kids ate them just fine as is.    All in all a good recipe!

text:
This was great, but very messy!!! It was my first time using a Crock Pot and I am still amazed at how easy it was.  I omitted the ranch salad dressing mix and the butter.  After reading the other reviews, it didn't seem to add much to the recipe other than to make it saltier.  I used two different wing sauces: Frank's Red Hot Wing Sauce and Stubb's Wing Sauce.  I recommend this combination because Frank's gives the chicken the classic buffalo flavor and color, while Stubb's gives more depth to the flavor.  Served it with blue cheese crumbles and blue cheese dressing on sesame potato rolls. The bf loved it!

This was SO GOOD!  I did cut the spicy by diluting the Frank's redhot wing sauce with chicken stock and a packet of ranch dressing mix for the first 2.5 hours.  I then drained the chicken, added butter, new hot sauce, and 1/2 a new packet of ranch dressing mix- I also shredded the chicken at this point.   Cooked for another 2 hours and it was perfect!  THANK you for this recipe idea and this is in the rotation - especially for football Sundays...Can't wait to try the leftovers on pizza...

text:
Hmmmm. I know many reviewers have been quite impressed with this, but I wasn't :-( My fiance and I were invited to a friends house to watch yesterday's U of IA vs. Ohio State football game and I wanted to bring something to "munch" on. Buffalo wings are usually a good game watching food, but I don't like them. When I saw this recipe, I thought it would be perfect - and filling! I guess I just don't care for the sandwich idea.... On second thought, when I go to BWW or Hooter's, I usually don't order "plain" (boneless) wings - I go for spicy garlic, mango habanero, etc. The hot sauce taste (I used Pete's wing sauce) was overwhelming, IMHO. I was hoping to taste a bit of 'zing' from the Ranch, but it was nonexistent (there doesn't seem to be much point in adding it... perhaps adding the entire packet would do the trick???). I also think that had I had toasted my kaiser rolls so they weren't so soft (which is great for hamburgers, but not for this; it just soaded thru the bun) these would have been better???? Oh, and I topped my sandwich with blue cheese dressing, but didn't really care for that either. I'm glad I didn't go thru the trouble of making it homemade. I might make this in the future (prep couldn't be easier - and frozen chicken breasts work great in the sc!) for buffalo chicken pizza, but wouldn't again if not for that. Thanks anyways :)

text:
We enjoyed this. I left out the butter at the end, to lower calories. It was still very good. We topped ours with bleu cheese dressing. This was a very low-fuss recipe! EDIT 5/06/10: I've made this several times. I find it helps to dump most of the juice right before the shredding step. You add more fresh sauce (the remaining 1/4 of the jar) at the end for flavor anyway. Thanks again for the recipe, we love this one!

country:
None
text:
Definitely good and healthier than traditional wings. I only used about 1 T dry ranch seasoning.  I added about 1-2 T each of honey, Worcestershire, and red wine vinegar. Finally I put a small can of low sodium chicken broth in with the hot sauce.  Instead of shredding I cut the cooked chicken breasts into large chunks and then returned it to the crock pot with 2+ T butter and placed on the warm setting.  Served on homemade buns (toasted with butter), with sliced sharp cheddar cheese, and slathered with a mixture of sour cream/spicy ranch dressing.  Didn't find this too salty.

text:
This was so yummy and so easy. I used 3/4 bottle (12 fl oz bottle) buffalo sauce, 1/2 bottle (8 fl oz bottle) ranch dressing, & 6 breast halves (1 pound). Put all at once in the slow cooker for 2 hours. Shred the chicken, add 1/2 stick butter, put on low for further 2 hours, then served it with ranch dressing on burger buns. So yummy!

text:
I absolutely love buffalo chicken wings.  I decided to halve this recipe as its only two of us. Instead of using our slow cooker, I decided to cook chicken in my Instant Pot  for an hour & 15 mins.  I used Franks but realized the 2 bottles I had were different labels. Aghast!! One was wing sauce the other Hot sauce.  I had already poured the hot sauce when I realized the difference. So note to self for future reference.  I then added the equal amount of Wing sauce.  I couldnt wait to try it, it came out so tender & minimal shredding was needed.  I found it to be very spicy for my taste  & a bit salty but that could have been my fault due to the Hot sauce confusion. I  will update when I use the correct sauce in future.  Thank you for an easy meal!

text:
I can't give this enough stars! I used four chicken breasts, 3/4 of a bottle of sweet baby rays buffalo sauce and a packet of hidden valley ranch dressing mix, low for six hours, then shredded it and returned it to crock pot (with the rest of the bottle of sauce) for an hour on warm. It was amazing! It has quite a kick but cheese and some ranch or mayo helps cut it back a bit. And I normally hate spicy things. Yum!!

country:
None
text:
Having made this for many years now, this is one of those failsafe recipes that's easily "tweakable" and great for serving a crowd. I always use thighs, as I find they're better suited for the crockpot. A bonus is that my crockpot is a beast and I can have this done from start to finish in 2 hours.  I use Frank's Red Hot sauce and serve on toasted onion buns with melted provolone, shredded lettuce, and a side of crispy onion rings. I keep bleu cheese dressing or crumbles on the side for those who want to add extras. Carmelized onions (or even raw for those like me who love raw onions)  make excellent toppings as well. This is made often at my house, and will continue on as a game day tradition!

country:
None
text:
I've made this a few times and recommend the following changes: I used boneless/skinless thighs instead of breast meat and omitted the butter as it is compensated by the extra fat content of the thighs. Almost any recipe for chicken breast can be improved by substituting the thigh which less expensive and more flavorful. I did try omitting the ranch dressing, because ordinarily ranch is an anathema to Buffalo wings (blue cheese all the way!), but it really works to add some flavors and umami to the preparation.
